data.title: 7 interesting things to know about British actor Kenneth Branagh
data.meta_description: Sir Kenneth Charles Branagh is an Irish-born actor, producer, screenwriter and director, known for his film and television adaptations of Shakespearean
data.text:
Sir Kenneth Charles Branagh is an Irish-born actor, producer, screenwriter and director, known for his film and television adaptations of Shakespearean plays, as well as blockbuster films like Thor and Cinderella. Kenneth Branagh has donned many professional hats, some to rave reviews. Although much of his work has been in theater and film, Branagh has been involved in the television industry. He has performed the lead roles of Hamlet and King Lear on BBC radio shows and has also performed in the voice acting narrator role for several audiobooks.

Kenneth Branagh’s Early Life and Rise to Fame

Branagh was born in Belfast, Northern Ireland on December 10, 1960, to working-class Protestants. His family moved to Reading, England, when he was just 9 years old, to escape a violent religious conflict now known as The Troubles. He quickly adopted an English accent to avoid bullying at school. As a teenager, he attended a play by Shakespeare. This upset him so much that he decided to pursue his career.

He appeared in numerous school productions and went on to study at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts, earning an outstanding reputation and the Bancroft Prize, which he used to join the Royal Shakespeare Company. Branagh co-founded with David Parfitt the Renaissance Theater Company, his own theater troupe.

Kenneth Branagh was one of the new waves of actors nurtured by RADA. At the academy, he played in several productions, including Henry V, which he later adapted into a film that marked him as a theater actor of undisputed talent.

His theater organization, the Renaissance Theater Company presented Twelfth Night, As You Like It, Looking Back in Anger, and other plays that made Branagh popular as a performer of Shakespeare’s works. He went on to direct and star in several film adaptations of the plays, including Henry V (1989) for which he won Best Actor and Best Director at the Oscars, Much Ado About Nothing (1993), Othello (1995), Hamlet (1996) which received four Oscar nods, and Love Labour’s Lost(2000) which was poorly received and nearly ended its career.

He also made two non-Shakespearean films during this period – Frankenstein (1994) and A Mid-Winter’s Tale (1995). Branagh, an acclaimed stage presence, decided to enter the world of blockbuster commercial success as an actor and director. He joined Marvel Comics as director behind Thor (2011) where he showcased his dramatic sensibilities in a storied cosmic adventure that grossed $449 million worldwide.

Kenneth Branagh worked his magic again in the live-action rendition of Cinderella, an adaptation that grossed over $542 million at the box office.

7 interesting things to know about the British actor

1. He is the first man to be nominated in five different categories in Oscar history – Best Director and Best Leading Actor for his work in ‘Henry V’, Best Adapted Screenplay for ‘Hamlet’, Best Live Action Short Film for “Swan Song”, and best actor in a supporting role for “My week with Marilyn”. He is also one of only two non-American actors to be nominated for Academy Awards for acting, directing and writing, the other being Roberto Benigni.

2. Branagh is the youngest actor to play the lead role in Shakespeare’s ‘Henry V’ in the history of the Royal Shakespeare Company. He was only 23 at the time.

3 He received several awards during his lifetime for his theatrical achievements, including the Laurence Olivier Theater Award for Most Promising Newcomer in 1983, the London Critics Circle Theater Award in 1988, the Gielgud Award for Excellence in dramatic arts in 2000 (the youngest actor ever). receive it), the Evening Standard Theater Award for Best Actor in 2004, and the Lifetime Achievement Award from RomaFictionFest on July 10, 2009.

4 He is one of 13 actors in Oscar history to be nominated for an Oscar for his role as King, and the last actor to be nominated for his role in a Shakespeare film.

5. Branagh’s 2008 film Valkyrie grossed $200 million worldwide, making it the fifth highest-grossing film of all time during World War II.

6. Othello (1995) is the only Shakespeare film adaptation in which Branagh starred, but did not direct. It was directed by Oliver Parker.

7. Her role as Berowne in ‘Love’s Labor Lost’ was first played by legendary writer Williams Shakespeare himself in the late 1500s.
